text: Are you looking for a macro audit to prune out underperforming content or something more tactical on improving a specific article?

elements.text: Are you looking for a macro audit to prune out underperforming content or something more tactical on improving a specific article?

text:
We use Copyscape too.

Doesn’t catch “similar” wording, but our editors often catch that when a writer’s tone suddenly changes for just a sentence or two.

It’s tough though. We work with over 150 writers and plagiarism is our #1 reason for offboarding them.

text:
Not efficient but the most effective: make your own–if you have the level of expertise required that’s by far the best way to go because you can cover important angles that general templates don’t have.

Here are some tips if you go that route:
• Use a combination of Google Presentation / Spreadsheet to store your findings
• Start with the audit goals (hint: make this about revenue)
• Focus on the pages that are most likely  to influence conversions (MOFU/BOFU).

elements.text:

Focus on the pages that are most likely  to influence conversions (MOFU/BOFU).

text: I have no advice (sorry) but just wanted to say I feel your pain :joy: I used Asana for content management at my last job and mostly liked it - but this exact thing was annoying. I wanted to be able to see due dates for individual tasks on top of when things were launching in a single view. Hoping someone else chimes in with a suggestion or alternative…

text:
We've recently seen a huge uplift of impressions and clicks to articles by adding videos that contain similar keywords.

If you have the budget for video, <https://searchengineland.com/google-recommends-placing-videos-on-dedicated-pages-for-maximum-exposure-375746|Google is adding a lot of recognition> to placing them on dedicated pages.

attachments.fallback: Search Engine Land: Google recommends placing videos on dedicated pages for maximum exposure

attachments.title: Google recommends placing videos on dedicated pages for maximum exposure

text:
There are things I really like about the concept, and mostly I haven't seen great execution. Curious to check this out.

Also, I don't recall whether it was on a subdomain or not, but the most recent "library not publication" that impressed me  was Carta — solving an interesting challenge of educating employees on what their stock awards mean

text:
The fact that so many people are feeling this when Asana is the leader in this space.... feels ripe for disruption. (I do love Notion though... :eyes: but not for task management) Glad to know it is actually Asana's product team that might be insane and not me.

We have a full growth ops team at my company so I think I'm going to push for my Airtable/Asana workflow (<https://www.jimmydaly.com/how-to-run-a-content-pipeline-with-airtable/|inspired by our fearless leader> <@UJG9WTEKG>) and try to get them to put it together for me with Zapier and webhooks. Even without Airtable <@U01EUMFKZQV>, they already told me that combo can automate pretty much anything in Asana, since Asana's automation rules are a joke. I always thought Zapier was just for connecting two apps, and you may already be aware of this, but wanted to share just in case.

If anyone besides my boss has an issue I can tell them they can become a blog contributor and then have a say on the process. I feel like that'll end the convo quickly :grin:

attachments.fallback: Jimmy Daly: Airtable + Zapier: Everything You Need to Run a High-Volume Editorial Workflow
attachments.text: The longer I work in content marketing, the more I realize that there are so many little things that make a great content program. It's about much more than great writing. A great final product is the result of a lot of moving pieces, typically held together by an editor.
attachments.title: Airtable + Zapier: Everything You Need to Run a High-Volume Editorial Workflow
